article: The Power of Fresh Starts Thirty years ago, I began my first year of teaching in Grade 2. One of the most _ students was a little boy who had a serious ADD . I had no _ in dealing with such a case, and I _ the year studying how to help him become a successful _ . There were many disappointing moments, but there was something pleasant about the boy who moved excitedly around my classroom.  _ the end of the school year came near, I heard a talk. The Grade 3 teachers were _ of having Stephen the following year. I considered it a lot, and I _ that I would be the best person to follow Stephen into Grade 3. My headmaster looked at me in _ , but he agreed to my plan. I will never forget that day when Stephen came to ask _ he was in my class again. I looked at him in the eye and said, "Well, Stephen, you're in my class because I asked for you." The little boy looked surprised. "You did? Why? " he asked. "Because I like you and want to keep _ you," I answered.  Stephen just stared at me. After a few moments, he _ and walked back to his seat with satisfaction. We never spoke of it again, but the two of us had many surprising learning breakthroughs that year. I believe those _ were more of a result of Stephen's knowing that I had put his previous year's mistakes behind him. Now I come to know that when I _ for one, I can improve his soul. Each season is a new beginning, a new way of thinking. Many students hope for a new start and are determined to act upon it. We need to pay attention to even the _ sign that students are looking for help.
